topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Shreyas Doshi, previews the episode’s core topics (pre-mortems, time use, levels of product work, strategy vs execution, prioritization), and sets up the “five big ideas” format.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Coda and Productboard, describing their value for team productivity, templates, roadmapping, and prioritization.

topics.title: Podcast format and Shreyas’s personal background
topics.summary: They outline the “five big ideas” structure, then Shreyas shares his upbringing in Mumbai, family influences, early interests (medicine, French), and eventual path into computer engineering.

topics.title: From engineering to product management
topics.summary: Shreyas explains dropping out of a CS PhD, navigating the early-2000s job market, getting early product exposure as an engineer, and choosing PM after realizing his comparative advantage.

topics.title: Lessons from Loudcloud/Opsware and high-caliber teams
topics.summary: They discuss Shreyas’s time at Loudcloud (Marc Andreessen/Ben Horowitz era), his unexpected vendor-management responsibilities, and what he learned from working with exceptionally strong teams.

topics.title: Key takeaways from Yahoo, Google, Twitter, Stripe
topics.summary: Rapid-fire reflections: Yahoo’s unified identity/account bundling, Google’s “think big” filter and revenue thresholds, Twitter’s network effects plus differentiation, and Stripe’s small teams with high judgment and low ego.

topics.title: Founder lessons: Larry, Jack, Patrick, John
topics.summary: Shreyas shares what he learned from leaders: Larry Page’s strategic foresight, Jack Dorsey’s listening and incisive questions, John Collison’s marketing instincts, and Patrick Collison’s clarity and values-through-example culture.

topics.title: Big Idea #1: Pre-mortems to prevent failures
topics.summary: Shreyas introduces pre-mortems as a proactive alternative to post-mortems, emphasizing the “assume it failed” prompt, psychological safety, and shared vocabulary (tigers, paper tigers, elephants) to surface risks early.

topics.title: How to run a pre-mortem meeting effectively
topics.summary: They cover practical execution: who to invite across functions, splitting engineering vs go-to-market for big launches, using silent writing + sharing, voting on scariest risks, and producing a prioritized action plan.

topics.title: Big Idea #2: LNO framework for PM time allocation
topics.summary: Shreyas explains Leverage/Neutral/Overhead tasks, how perfectionism misallocates time, and why the same activity (bugs, notes) can be L/N/O depending on context and stakes.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Sprig, highlighting in-product surveys and rapid prototype/mock testing to gather user insights quickly.

topics.title: Identifying true leverage tasks and beating procrastination
topics.summary: Shreyas describes how L-tasks are often the ones you avoid (strategy, alignment, hard conversations), plus tactics like “placebo productivity” and changing location to trigger focus and execution.

topics.title: Big Idea #3 begins: Three levels of product work
topics.summary: They transition into the framework of impact, execution, and optics, setting up how misalignment on which level matters most can create tension—illustrated via a CEO product review scenario (discussion begins but is cut off).
